title: Environment alias
body:
It would be great to have environment aliases. I.e. `spack env alias myenv someexistingenv` would create a symbolic link _myenv_ pointing to _someexistingenv_, so that `spack env activate myenv` would activate `someexistingenv`.

### Rationale

I have the following use case: I have installed spack on a project directory of a supercomputer, accessible to myself and a handful of people who are users of whatever software I have installed in this spack. I periodically install a new environment for them with, for example, the name `myenv08042020`. The name is always `myenv` followed by the date (in European format) when the environment was built. I do not erase older environments because (1) maybe there is a bug in the new environment I've installed and I want to be able to revert back to an older one, and (2) I want to be able to reuse dependencies that haven't been updated from one environment to another.

The users have a bunch of scripts in which they have to do `spack env activate myenv08042020` (or whatever environment is the latest one). Hence every time I release a new environment, I have to tell them to change their scripts.

It would be great if I could just create an alias `myenv` pointing to whatever environment I want them to use at a given moment. They would just keep `spack env activate myenv` in their scripts.

### Description

<!--*Describe the solution you'd like and the alternatives you have considered.*-->
See thee solution above. The only alternative I have found so far is to give the users some bash code that does essentially a `spack env list | grep myenv` and pick the last line, put it in a variable `envname` and do `spack env activate $envname`. This is not ideal because it necessarily picks the latest environment, which may not be the one I want them to use.
